title: Mathlib Imports
content: We import `Squarefree` from NumberTheory for the squarefree predicate, and Filter/Topology for asymptotic statements.
mathContext: Squarefree n means no prime p has p² | n. Equivalently, in the prime factorization n = p₁^{e₁} ⋯ pₖ^{eₖ}, all exponents eᵢ ≤ 1.

title: Property P Definition
content: **Property P:** For all n ≥ 1, only finitely many a ∈ A have n + a squarefree. Intuitively, A is 'anti-squarefree'—adding any fixed n destroys squarefreeness for almost all elements.
mathContext: If A has property P, then for each n, the set {a ∈ A : n + a is squarefree} is finite. This is a strong sparsity condition on A.

title: Property Q Definition
content: **Property Q:** Infinitely many n have n + a squarefree for all a < n in A. This is a 'pro-squarefree' condition—infinitely often, every translate is squarefree.
mathContext: Property Q is easier to satisfy than P. The squarefree numbers themselves have property Q with optimal density 6/π².

title: The Squarefree Set
content: The set of squarefree natural numbers: {1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, ...}. Missing numbers are divisible by some p².
mathContext: The density of squarefree numbers is 6/π² = ∏_p (1 - 1/p²) ≈ 0.6079. This product formula connects to the Riemann zeta function: 6/π² = 1/ζ(2).

title: Squarefree Examples
content: We verify that 1, 2, 6 are squarefree (no square factor > 1) while 4 = 2² and 12 = 4·3 are not. The `native_decide` tactic computes these directly.
mathContext: Checking squarefreeness: trial divide by 4, 9, 25, ... up to n. For small n, this is efficient. For large n, factorization is needed.

title: The Magic Constant 6/π²
content: The density of squarefree numbers is **6/π² ≈ 0.6079**. This equals 1/ζ(2) where ζ is the Riemann zeta function.
mathContext: By the Euler product, 1/ζ(2) = ∏_p (1 - 1/p²), which counts the probability that a random integer is not divisible by p² for any prime p. This is the squarefree density.

title: Property P Implies Density Zero
content: **van Doorn-Tao:** Any sequence with property P has density 0, meaning aⱼ/j → ∞ as j → ∞.
mathContext: The proof shows that for any P-sequence, the counting function A(x) = |{a ∈ A : a ≤ x}| satisfies A(x)/x → 0.

title: Arbitrarily Slow Decay for P
content: **van Doorn-Tao:** For any function f → ∞, there exists a P-sequence with aⱼ/j ≤ f(j). P-sequences can have density going to 0 arbitrarily slowly.
mathContext: This is an existence result using probabilistic or greedy construction. The sequence is not given explicitly.

title: Property Q Upper Density Bound
content: **van Doorn-Tao:** Any Q-sequence has upper density at most 6/π². The squarefree numbers achieve this bound exactly.
mathContext: For random n, the probability that n + a is squarefree for all small a depends on the density of A. Optimizing gives the 6/π² bound.

title: Special Sequences Have Property Q
content: The sequences 2ⁿ ± 1 and n! ± 1 have property Q. These grow fast enough that infinitely many n have all translates squarefree. Whether they have property P remains open.
mathContext: Fast growth ensures the sequence is sparse, making it easier to find n where all a ∈ A ∩ [1,n) give n + a squarefree.
